children.value: The third planet from the Sun and the only known world to harbor life. Earth is a differentiated, water-rich terrestrial planet with a nitrogen–oxygen atmosphere, active plate tectonics, and a protective magnetosphere that together maintain a surface stable enough for oceans, weather, and complex biospheres.
Axial tilt of ~23.44° drives seasons. Precession cycle ~26,000 years.
Water cloud cover typically 50–70%. Variable by season and region.
Auroral ovals near the poles caused by solar wind interactions with Earth's geomagnetic field.
From deep space up to ≈ −4.0.
N/A
N/A
Best seen at high latitudes; emissions from atomic oxygen (green/red) and molecular nitrogen (violet).

Fourth planet from the Sun. A cold, desert world with a thin carbon‑dioxide atmosphere, global dust storms, and a surface shaped by volcanism, impacts, and ancient water flows. Target of extensive robotic exploration and a prime candidate for future human missions.
Seasons similar to Earth's due to ~25° tilt; precession and obliquity vary over long cycles, driving climate change.
Thin water‑ice and CO₂ clouds; frequent dust hazes and planet‑encircling storms in some years.
Diffuse aurora driven by solar wind interacting with crustal magnetic anomalies; no global dipole field.
As bright as ≈ −2.9 at favorable opposition.
Best near opposition (≈ every 26 months).
Aurora detected by MAVEN/other missions; driven by crustal fields and solar activity.

The largest planet in the Solar System. A hydrogen–helium gas giant with powerful zonal winds, massive storms (including the Great Red Spot), a faint ring system, and an extensive family of moons. Generates intense radiation belts and a vast magnetosphere.
Small axial tilt yields weak seasons; atmospheric bands and storms dominate visual changes.
Ammonia ice upper clouds, ammonium hydrosulfide middle, water clouds deeper; banded belts/zones and long‑lived vortices.
Extremely powerful auroras; driven by rapid rotation and interactions with Io's plasma torus within a vast magnetosphere.
As bright as ≈ −2.9 at opposition.
Best near opposition (≈ every 13 months).
Powerful ultraviolet and X‑ray auroras observed; strongly linked to Io's volcanism and magnetospheric currents.

The sixth planet from the Sun and a hydrogen–helium gas giant famed for its luminous ring system. Saturn’s banded atmosphere hosts powerful jet streams and storms above layers of ammonia, ammonium hydrosulfide, and water clouds. Dozens of moons and a broad magnetosphere complete the system.
Pronounced seasons due to ~27° tilt; ring opening angle changes over the 29.5‑year orbit.
N/A (gas giant; no solid surface)
Ammonia ice upper clouds; ammonium hydrosulfide middle layers; water clouds deeper. Prominent rings cast moving shadows.
Bright ultraviolet auroras; powered by rapid rotation and solar‑wind interactions within a large, symmetric magnetic field.
As bright as ≈ −0.55 at opposition.
Best near opposition (≈ every 378 days).
Polar auroras imaged in ultraviolet and infrared; dynamics influenced by ring–magnetosphere interactions.

Seventh planet from the Sun. An ice giant with a pale blue‑green hue from atmospheric methane, faint banding, and a tilted rotation axis of ~98° that effectively puts the planet on its side. Rings and dozens of moons orbit within a lopsided magnetosphere.
Extreme ~98° tilt leads to decades‑long polar days/nights; seasons are dramatic and asymmetric.
N/A (ice giant; no solid surface)
Faint bands with methane haze; seasonal polar hoods and occasional bright storms; methane absorption gives blue‑green color.
Auroras observed but irregular; magnetic axis highly tilted and offset from the planet’s center, leading to complex interactions.
Down to ≈ +5.7 at opposition (dark skies).
Best near opposition (≈ every 369 days).
Auroras detected by Voyager 2 and telescopes; variability tied to solar activity and tilted magnetosphere.

Eighth planet from the Sun. A deep‑blue ice giant with supersonic winds, dynamic storms like the Great Dark Spot, and faint rings. Atmosphere rich in hydrogen, helium, and methane above icy mantle layers and a likely rocky core.
~28° tilt produces Earth‑like seasons over a 165‑year orbit; storms and bands vary with season and internal heat.
N/A (ice giant; no solid surface)
High‑altitude methane haze with deeper water‑ammonia clouds; frequent fast‑moving storms and bright companion clouds.
Patchy, transient auroras; magnetic axis tilted ~47° and offset from center, producing complex solar‑wind interactions.
Around +7.8 at opposition; requires binoculars or a telescope.
Best near opposition (≈ every 367 days).

value.value: Johann Galle & Heinrich d'Arrest (pred. Le Verrier)

children.value: Auroras observed by Hubble and other instruments; variability tied to solar wind and tilted magnetosphere.

Small, dense, and airless, Mercury is the Sun’s closest planet. It is a heavily cratered world with a large iron core, a tenuous exosphere, extreme temperature swings, and a weak global magnetic field. Its 3:2 spin–orbit resonance produces long days and short years.
Axial tilt is near zero; seasons are minimal. 3:2 spin–orbit resonance makes one solar day ≈ 176 Earth days.
Extremely tenuous exosphere (~10⁻¹⁵ bar).
No clouds; airless surface of cratered silicate rock and regolith.
Weak global magnetosphere; sputtering creates a sodium tail and faint emissions, not classical auroras.
Up to ≈ −2.6 near greatest elongation (low over horizon).
Best at morning/evening elongations; low altitude makes observation challenging.
Faint sodium tail and localized emissions observed; space weather strongly modulates the exosphere.

Second planet from the Sun. A rocky world cloaked by a dense, reflective CO₂ atmosphere with global sulfuric‑acid clouds. Slow retrograde rotation, extreme surface temperatures, and volcanic plains make Venus a harsh, hidden twin to Earth.
Retrograde rotation (spins backward); solar day ≈ 116.75 Earth days.
Global sulfuric‑acid cloud decks with thick haze; super‑rotating winds circling the planet in ~4 days.
Induced magnetosphere from the solar wind; nightside emissions observed but not classic dipole‑driven auroras.
As bright as ≈ −4.9 (evening/morning star).
Best at greatest elongations (≈ 47° from the Sun).
Nightside ultraviolet emissions observed; interactions dominated by the induced magnetotail and solar wind.

Once the ninth planet, Pluto is a small, icy world in the Kuiper Belt. It has a nitrogen‑dominated atmosphere that expands and collapses with the seasons, varied terrains of nitrogen, methane, and water ice, and a large moon, Charon, with which it forms a binary system.
Retrograde rotation with ~122° tilt; 248‑year orbit drives extreme seasonal changes and atmospheric collapse/reinflation.
No true clouds; extensive layered haze to >200 km composed of hydrocarbons and tholins (New Horizons).
No intrinsic field; solar‑wind interactions create a long ion tail. Haze layers dominate optical phenomena.
Around +14 at opposition; requires a mid‑size telescope.
Best near opposition (≈ yearly from Earth’s view).
No classical auroras; New Horizons revealed extensive atmospheric haze and variable escape to a long tail.
